captions.text:
Here ladies and gentlemen, I am going to show you 
 what the toilets look like here in Korea.

This is the boys' washroom, and here is something that I have never 
 seen before. (For more videos on Bucheon, Korea, go to http://www.eatyourkimchi.com)
Let's open up one of these stalls.
This is their toilet.
Um, it's not a urinal, in fact, this is on the ground.
If you back up, you see there it is on the ground.
Uh, I'm not really sure how to use one of these things.
Um... so... I don't want to imagine it,
but for those of us who prefer the traditional kind of toilets,
here indeed, you have one.
It's right there.
Um, do you notice something weird about this?
Let me back it up for you right here.
There is a toilet and you see,
there are no walls around it.
So, if you want to sit down to take a poop,
uh, everyone's going to be there, looking at you.
Uh, is this the Korean way of doing things? I'm not really sure.
I know that if I was in elementary school, I'd be really embarrassed
to be pooping in public. But, there you go.
This is what their toilets look like. Well...

comments.text:
A friend of mine in high school used to leave the door open and recline 
while he pooped. Then he'd wave and say "Hello."﻿
comments.author: slytown

comments.text:
The only thing preventing me from traveling.. I just want to be able to 
take a dump in peace, without having to squat or have people stand around 
me, or having to walk to a shed.

Just a toilet. That's all I require.﻿

comments.text:
The first time I encountered a toilet like this was in Russia when I was 
12. There was a slight difference though: it was pretty much a hole in the 
ground. There was PLENTY of room to take care of business and I was so 
confused at first. I'm happy to say that I figured it out and successfully 
took care of business.

With all that training, I knew just what to do when I saw this baby in 
Korea. :D﻿

comments.author: Sandra Ahlin

comments.text:
Yeah - those squatter toilets took a 'wee' (feeling so clever at that one) 
bit of getting used to for me. But once you're used to 'em, and manage not 
to piss on the pack of your pulled down pants (haven't done that, but can't 
help but wonder if a few folks have managed to do it accidentally), they 
aren't that bad. They seem to be a more natural 'poop position', so to 
speak, than a western style pedestal toilet.

But they do look rather like a urinal on the floor.﻿
comments.author: kimchiman1000

comments.text:
LOL!

Just a quick comment here on your Korean Toilet Paper video - there's a 
Korean owned Japanese restaurant in my neighborhood. And I was quite 
entertained by the little sign they put in there, asking the customers to 
please NOT put the used TP in the toilet. I seriously doubt that anyone 
except the Korean staff abide by that sign.

The sign states that the TP 'makes the toilet sick'.﻿

comments.text:
This is simply NOT true. You may find this kind of toilets in the country 
side, or some lost rest areas on the road but definitively NEVER SEEN that 
in Seoul. In fact this video is from Bucheon (far suburb of Seoul, half way 
to the airport), and in a school. That's definitively not what you will get 
on a daily basis, especially as a tourist. ps: I'm in Korea for a few 
month, already 3rd time I'm coming here.

comments.text:
Squat toilets have actually many benefits especially when it comes to 
public use. This helps prevent fecal stagnation,a prime factor in colon 
cancer and appendicitis Protects your health since the public toilets are 
used by lot of ppl & not all toilets are clean...Also as funny as it sounds 
'squatting' helps prepare one for a more natural delivery. Personally in my 
house i have a common flush toilet but when i need to use the toilet in a 
public place i'm quite relieved when i see a aquat one:)
comments.author: MsAmadita

comments.text:
These toilets really aren't that bad. You may think you can avoid using 
them or whatever, but when you gotta go... You'll use it. I was in China 
for a week, and you couldn't avoid squat toilets no matter where you were. 
McDonalds? Squat. Fancy club in Shanghai? Squat. You'll get the hang of 
them after the first time or two :).. Just remember to bring tissues around 
with you.
